title: Are there any modern classical composers? - Quora

response.answer_text: Are you serious? You could have simply googled or wiki-ed this…. You should ignore the person discussing Film Composers, as those are only tangentially relevant. Universities and Conservatories have continued to produce and study classical music’s development, which has continued from the Middle Ages and never stopped to the present. Now this is in no way a comprehensive list, but if you simply pick up a music history book, here’s some of the renown composers they will list from the beginning of the twentieth-century to the present: (Before WWII) Debussy, Ravel, Scriabin, Schoenberg, Berg, Webern, Stravinsky, Bartok, Hindemith, Prokofiev, Shostakovich, Ives, Cowell, Barber, Copland, Crawford, Ruggles, Nancarrow, etc. etc. etc. (After WWII) Britten, Messiaen, Stockhausen, Boulez, Stockhausen, Xenakis, Cage, Brown, Ligeti, Penderecki, Lutoslawski, Young, Riley, Glass, Reich, Adams, Scelsi, Lachemann, Grisey, Mureil, Norgard, Saariaho, Gubaidalina, Gorecki, Part, Ferneyhough, Davies, Knussen, Crumb, Corigliano, Carter, Davidovsky, Babbit, Chen Yi, Daugherty, Bolcom, Albright, Schwantner, Druckman, Zhou Long, Isang Yun, (out of breath…not even possible to list all the “major” composers here…) These are all people commonly studied and performed many many many times every year…..[sorry I did not list all the first names.] EDIT: I was not disparaging Film Music in this answer (in fact, film composers borrow and/or are influenced by many of the composers I just listed,) I was just presenting composers that are considered as a continuation of concert and art music as the way it is presented and taught universally in history classes throughout the world as well as who is included on concerts with other Classical repertoire from earlier eras. Second Edit: If you mean “in the style of….” then see my previous answer Michael Sidney Timpson's answer to Are there any contemporary composers that write in the baroque or classicistic style?

It depends on what you mean by “classical.” If you mean sounding like Mozart or Schubert, probably no. I recall a graduate student at UC Berkeley who improvised, pretty well, in a style that was Romantic, e.g., Liszt, Brahms. I don’t know what became of him, because he didn’t write his improvs down, just played them on piano. A former UCLA colleague, Richard Grayson, could do the same thing with Baroque music, but his own music was distinctly modern. On the other hand, if you mean composers of what I call “concert music,” they are all around you. You just don’t appreciate their work like you do earlier music. I don’t think that means they aren’t serious composers, they simply have taken on qualities of music of the 20th century, like Stravinsky, Rachmaninoff, Schoenberg, Cage, Feldman, et al. The repertoire of Kronos (the string quartet) is filled with examples that span the entire stylistic range of concert music, nearly all of it 20th century.

Good heavens yes! Though this does depend on how you define “classical”. If what you mean by classical is a composer who writes music just like Mozart or Bach, then, no, there are none. Well, there may be a few, but their music is of little interest, and so their music is rarely if ever performed. However, among the composers writing some very engaging music these days are Randall Woolf, Frederick Rzewski, Elliot Carter (though recently deceased, he was writing music until the age of 103), Marc-André Hamelin, Christopher Rouse, Richard Danielpour, Jennifer Higdon, Ellen Zwilich, Jonathan Dove, Fazil Say, York Höller, Cheryl Frances-Hoad, and Kaija Saariaho. All worth checking into; they all have written some very engaging and beautiful music.

What a strange question. If you mean by “classical” those who write in the style popular in European concert halls and drawing rooms from roughly 1770 to 1820, then, no, of course not! Why would a modern composer be interested in chewing over something that has already been done two centuries or more ago?If you mean by “classical” the type of music performed in concert halls by symphony orchestras, operas, chamber music, etc. then, of course, there are thousands, tens of thousands, 100’s of, or maybe millions of people writing what can loosely be described as “classical” music. We are living in the most creative time in human history with some of the most amazing music being written and performed, most brilliant books being written, most creative and dynamic art being produced than has ever happened in any previous time in human history.

“Classical” music is music that was composed in the 17th, 18th and 19th centuries. Therefore 20th and 21st century music doesn’t qualify by definition. If instead of “classical” music you would ask if serious music, intended for classically trained musicians and audiences is being composed today, there is lots of it. Living composers such as John Adams, Phillip Glass, Jennifer Higdon and many others are composing works that have enduring characteristics and will very likely be played for many years hence.

I don’t know if he can be considered a “classical” musician, but James Horner is making some amazing instrumentals that could be considered classical. While admittedly I haven’t heard too many of his songs, his soundtrack to the 2012 remake Karate Kid was absolutely brilliant. Half a century from now, some emo teen is going to look back and say that he defined the 2000s classical scene. I guess from some perspectives, John Williams, the only movie soundtrack composer that requires no introduction, could also be considered a classical artist. His work on Harry Potter, for example, could almost certainly pass as the work of an early Beethoven if it wasn’t so well known.

There are thousands, but are there any modern classical composer fans? I studied modern classical music in college and loved it- but beyond my other composition student friends, no one else loved it. The other music students hated it and only played our stuff because their teachers told them it was good for them, and literally no one else in the university cared for us at all… not even the music of our professors or guest composers. The truth is that classical music is a dead genre. There are many reasons I think it's dead (I think musicians killed it and prefer it dead), but whatever the case, it's a genre dedicated to preservation rather than encouraging new voices. Now days I perform Gregorian Chant and write poppy modal music- I preserve what I need to preserve and innovate where innovation is welcomed.

The Soviet composer Georgy Sviridov is a mid-20th century neo-Romantic Russian composer. His piano trio, which I believe has won the Stalin Prize in the 50s (what a terrible prize to win!), is a very good place to start I think. Virgil Thomson is another mid-20th century name that I have recently came across with. He sounds very classical. From the contemporary (1980s on) names I know, Jennifer Higdon and Sally Beamish come closest to the old, romantic or classic styles.

I am a classical composer. As a teenager I composed several works that professors and critics have been defined superior or equal to Chopin, Rachmaninoff and Debussy (they are the impromptu op.18 n.2, impromptu op 18 n.1, and "Festa"),tracks present on my first album soon available for listening in the final version also online. Draft version of my impromptu op 18 n.2:  "Spindrifts", the single from my first album "Oversound" is pretty neoclassical,it received 1 million views on fb. It is an outgoing album that required 13 years of work whose video clip is entirely recorded in the sea:

Alma Deutscher (born 2005) is a young composer who creates music very much inspired by the styles of Mozart, Schubert, and Tchaikovsky. Her musical training was similar to that of students in the Neapolitan conservatories of the 18th century. There are people who think they are. They are like sad, evaporated dust compared to the great composers we typically think of as “composers”. The whole idea of writing new classical music was ruined in the 20th Century by terrible composers who thought that being novel to the point of absurdity was enough. Very little written since 1953 has entered the standard repertoire. It is unlikely the art will ever be rehabilitated.
Karl Jenkins? John Rutter? There are some tonal neoclassical conservative composers still out there… even some Stravinsky pieces and movie composers.

Benjamin Britten. Vaughan-Williams. Edward Elgar. Leonard Bernstein. Stravinsky. Mahler. Saint-Saens. Satie. Debussy. Some of them are end 19. and beginning of 20. century. None of them is at the level of the “greats”: Bach, Mozart, Beethoven, Brahms, Wagner!!!
In a word; Scores. See Mr. Timpsons post below, you will get years of exploration into the genre just searching into the names.
